div.head: Glossary
div.p: This glossary contains a list of technical terms used in the 'Getting Started using TEI' series. It will be expanded with the publication of new articles in the series. The definitions are not aimed at full technical accuracy but rather at providing the beginner with a first working definition of the relevant concepts.

item.gloss: In XML, a property of an element. Properties are given in the opening tag of an element.
Cascading Stylesheets: define styles for HTML pages (borders, margins, font size, etc.). Not to be confused with XSLT stylesheets.
Document Type Definition: older XML schema language, now largely superseded by RELAX NG and W3C XML Schema.

In text encoding based on XML, a fragment of text delimited by opening and closing tags. The text is described by a hierarchical structure of elements. Elements may contain oher elements and/or text, but can also be empty. Properties of elements can be given in attributes.
HyperText Markup Language, the language used to write web pages.
Namespaces are collections of XML elements that belong to some common vocabulary. All TEI elements belong to the TEI namespace. XML documents can use elements from multiple namespaces.

Optical Character Recognition: Process whereby a computer program interprets a scanned page and outputs (something more or less like) the text written on that page. The text can then be edited in e.g. a word processor such as MS Word.
One Document Does it all: document that defines and describes a TEI schema, basis for generating the schema. Roma is the TEI's web-based tool for editing ODD files and generating schemas.
One variety of XML schema, characterized by simplicity. See
The TEI's web-based tool for creating and modifying ODD documents and turning them into schemas. Available at

A schema describes the elements and attributes (and their combinations) that can occur in an XML document. A schema is necessary for XML validation. The TEI uses three schema languages DTD, XSD (also known as W3C Schema) and Relax NG. The 'Getting started using TEI series' uses Relax NG.

Markup that is not present in the text, at the location of the phenomenon that is being annotated, but elsewhere. The stand-off markup will then use a pointing mechanism to refer to the location that it belongs to.

Text Encoding Initiative.

A Uniform Resource Locator may be an internet address, such as , a filename, or a location in the current document (by using the value of an xml:id attribute somewhere in the document, preceded by '#'.) A URL need not be absolute (contain a full address) but can also be relative to the current address, such as 'images/page4.jpg'.
Validation is the process whereby a program checks an XML document for well-formedness (obeying XML syntax rules) and validity (obey constraints defined in the XML schema).

What You See Is What You Get. In modern word processors, what you see is what you get: the document on the screen looks like the document that comes out of the printer. Word processors can work this way because the information in the document serves a single purpose: it is meant to look a certain way and that is it. The information in an XML document is meant to be used in multiple ways, and therefore there is no single 'what you get'.

eXtensible Mark-up Language. For the purposes of the TEI, XML can be seen as a generic syntax for encoding properties, structural and others, of texts. The TEI encoding scheme is applied using XML. But non-textual data structures can also be expressed using XML.
An XML schema language defined by the World Wide Web Consortium.
eXtensible Stylesheet Language - Transformations. Language that is used to define transformations from XML documents into new XML documents, HTML documents, or plain text documents.
Software used to compress and bundle (= 'zip') one or more files into a single package, facilitating quick and easy transport over the network.
